lexUnit.name: hoot.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: (of owls) to make their natural throat noise

sentence.text: A taxi hooted outside and Elaine rushed from the room , leaving a scent of Estee Lauder and face powder .
` There is an old saying that every time an owl hoots a woman has been unfaithful , " she added , lifting the candlestick and looking round .
The first time Wexford noticed this -- she was then about six -- he almost hooted aloud , so grotesque was the likeness between this exquisite piece of doll 's flesh and her gross progenitor .
Mr Tuckett hooted again .
Vic hoots impatiently at the barrier ; the security man 's face appears at the window and flashes an ingratiating smile .
Then an owl suddenly hooted nearby , making her jump , and she hastily decided she had done enough for one evening .
An owl hooted somewhere .
Beyond , the post van hooted indignantly .
A train hooted and a moment later flashed past with a shriek .
They were hooting and flapping their great woolly arms as they tried to climb on to a private jetty .
The other homeward traffic rushed past them ; one or two cars hooted because Kev had stopped in a very awkward spot for anyone to pass .
The owls hooted in Highgate , in Wimbledon , in Dulwich .
Lee and Leslie began hooting with glee .
A car hooted behind them .
Delegates hooted in disgust or yanked up their ties to imitate nooses .
But when your German friends saw us doing this , they hooted with derision .
Half out of her dress , she hooted with amusement .
The Doctor looked around from under the stairwell when the alarm began hooting , but saw nothing .
On the road , the cars hooted , bumper to bumper in the week-end crawl to the coast .
A single owl hooted .
Truck drivers hooted , children stared , and just about everyone laughed or waved .
His drinking buddies cheered and hooted .
Then we realised the mistake was ours : we were heading down one of Madeira 's ordinary roads , with cars hooting to overtake on both sides .
